articles.headline: ‘Chilling Effect’: Arrest of Journalist Makes Covering Russia Even Tougher
articles.snippet: The detention of the Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich poses new obstacles for Western journalists seeking to report on Vladimir V. Putin’s rule.
articles.abstract: The detention of the Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich poses new obstacles for Western journalists seeking to report on Vladimir V. Putin’s rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: The exodus began roughly a year ago, in the first days of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Western news organizations, confronting a harsh crackdown on free speech by President Vladimir V. Putin, pulled correspondents from Moscow and suspended their news gathering in Russia. The risk to journalists, in a country where describing a war as a “war” was suddenly a crime, was too great.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Twitter Takes Aim at Posts That Link to Its Rival Substack
articles.snippet: Elon Musk’s company made the norm-shattering move two days after the publishing start-up Substack unveiled a Twitter-like service.
articles.abstract: Elon Musk’s company made the norm-shattering move two days after the publishing start-up Substack unveiled a Twitter-like service.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On Wednesday, the newsletter service Substack announced that it had built a Twitter competitor. On Thursday, Twitter prevented Substack writers from sharing tweets in their newsletters. And on Friday, Twitter took steps to block Substack newsletters from circulating on the platform.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Ryan Mac

articles.headline: Outrage at G.O.P. Could Propel Expelled Democrats Right Back to House
articles.snippet: A day after two young Black lawmakers were expelled from the Tennessee legislature, momentum was building to reappoint them directly back to their seats.
articles.abstract: A day after two young Black lawmakers were expelled from the Tennessee legislature, momentum was building to reappoint them directly back to their seats.
articles.lead_paragraph: Expelled by their Republican colleagues for an act of protest, Justin Jones and Justin J. Pearson were no longer members of the Tennessee House of Representatives on Friday. They could not advocate for their constituents in Nashville and Memphis, take to the floor again to push for gun control legislation or even access the building after hours.
articles.byline: By Eliza Fawcett and Rick Rojas

articles.headline: New Batch of Classified Documents Appears on Social Media Sites
articles.snippet: Secret documents that appear to detail American national security secrets on Ukraine, the Middle East and China have surfaced online.
articles.abstract: Secret documents that appear to detail American national security secrets on Ukraine, the Middle East and China have surfaced online.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new batch of classified documents that appear to detail American national security secrets from Ukraine to the Middle East to China surfaced on social media sites on Friday, alarming the Pentagon and adding turmoil to a situation that seemed to have caught the Biden administration off guard.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: Banks Are Closing Customer Accounts, With Little Explanation
articles.snippet: Increasing attention to suspicious-seeming transactions has led to some people suddenly losing access to their bank accounts. The reasons are often a mystery.
articles.abstract: Increasing attention to suspicious-seeming transactions has led to some people suddenly losing access to their bank accounts. The reasons are often a mystery.
articles.lead_paragraph: Naafeh Dhillon had just left the holiday light show at Saks Fifth Avenue in New York when he learned that all of his bank accounts had mysteriously gone dark.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Georgia Looms Next After Trump’s Indictment in New York
articles.snippet: Former President Donald J. Trump now faces a very different legal challenge in the culmination of a more than two-year Atlanta investigation into election interference.
articles.abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump now faces a very different legal challenge in the culmination of a more than two-year Atlanta investigation into election interference.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The indictment of Donald J. Trump in New York over hush-money payments to a porn star was a global spectacle, with the former president glumly returning to his old stomping grounds in Manhattan as TV networks closely tracked his procession of black SUVs on their way to the courthouse.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: Can We No Longer Believe Anything We See?
articles.snippet: Human eyes — and even technology — often struggle to identify images created by artificial intelligence. Experts fear that may hasten an erosion of trust in media, in government and in society.
articles.abstract: Human eyes — and even technology — often struggle to identify images created by artificial intelligence. Experts fear that may hasten an erosion of trust in media, in government and in society.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seeing has not been believing for a very long time. Photos have been faked and manipulated for nearly as long as photography has existed.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: The Russians Took Their Children. These Mothers Went and Got Them Back.
articles.snippet: Making a nerve-wracking 3,000-mile journey from Ukraine, into Russia-occupied territory, and back again, a group of mothers managed to recover their children from the custody of the Russian authorities.
articles.abstract: Making a nerve-wracking 3,000-mile journey from Ukraine, into Russia-occupied territory, and back again, a group of mothers managed to recover their children from the custody of the Russian authorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: For weeks after Russian troops forcibly removed Natalya Zhornyk’s teenage son from his school last fall, she had no idea where he was or what had happened to him.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Daniel Berehulak

articles.headline: Leaked Documents Reveal Depth of U.S. Spy Efforts and Russia’s Military Struggles
articles.snippet: The information, exposed on social media sites, also shows that U.S. intelligence services are eavesdropping on important allies.
articles.abstract: The information, exposed on social media sites, also shows that U.S. intelligence services are eavesdropping on important allies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A trove of leaked Pentagon documents reveals how deeply Russia’s security and intelligence services have been penetrated by the United States, demonstrating Washington’s ability to warn Ukraine about planned strikes and providing an assessment of the strength of Moscow’s war machine.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: At Stanford Law School, the Dean Takes a Stand for Free Speech. Will It Work?
articles.snippet: After a student protest, Jenny S. Martinez wrote a much-praised memo defending academic freedom. But that protest shows how complicated protecting free speech can be.
articles.abstract: After a student protest, Jenny S. Martinez wrote a much-praised memo defending academic freedom. But that protest shows how complicated protecting free speech can be.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stanford Law School was under extraordinary pressure.
articles.byline: By Vimal Patel

articles.headline: El Salvador Decimated Its Ruthless Gangs. But at What Cost?
articles.snippet: In the year since El Salvador declared a state of emergency, the government has delivered a stunning blow to the gangs that were once the ultimate authority in much of the country.
articles.abstract: In the year since El Salvador declared a state of emergency, the government has delivered a stunning blow to the gangs that were once the ultimate authority in much of the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the MS-13 gang ran the neighborhood of Las Margaritas, one of its strongholds in El Salvador, there were rules you had to follow to stay alive.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Daniele Volpe

articles.headline: New Mexico Is Losing a Form of Spanish Spoken Nowhere Else on Earth
articles.snippet: A dialect from the state’s earliest Spanish-speaking settlers has endured for over 400 years in the state’s remote mountain villages. But its time may be running out.
articles.abstract: A dialect from the state’s earliest Spanish-speaking settlers has endured for over 400 years in the state’s remote mountain villages. But its time may be running out.
articles.lead_paragraph: QUESTA, N.M. — When the old regulars gather at Cynthia Rael-Vigil’s coffee shop in Questa, N.M., a village nestled in the snow-capped Sangre de Cristo Mountains, they sip lattes and lavender lemonade and gossip in Spanish.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Desiree Rios

articles.headline: $388 in Sushi. Just a $20 Tip: The Brutal Math of Uber Eats and DoorDash
articles.snippet: Delivery drivers were hailed as pandemic heroes. But they say the rise of contactless delivery has made customers less inclined to tip generously and gig work is becoming an even harder way to make a living.
articles.abstract: Delivery drivers were hailed as pandemic heroes. But they say the rise of contactless delivery has made customers less inclined to tip generously and gig work is becoming an even harder way to make a living.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brantley Bush couldn’t shake the fear that he was about to be ripped off.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning and Mark Abramson

articles.headline: ‘Super Mario Bros. Movie’ Brings Family Box Office Roaring Back
articles.snippet: The film’s blockbuster opening weekend raised hopes that animation, once one of Hollywood’s safest bets, had recovered from the pandemic.
articles.abstract: The film’s blockbuster opening weekend raised hopes that animation, once one of Hollywood’s safest bets, had recovered from the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Movie theaters have struggled to recover from the pandemic, in part, because the once-reliable family audience has wandered. Last year, family-oriented films — largely animation — represented 17 percent of worldwide ticket sales, about half of what they were in 2019.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Will North Carolina Be the ‘Beginning of the End’ of the Medicaid Expansion Fight?
articles.snippet: Intense patient advocacy, shifting politics, a determined Democratic governor and a handful of maverick Republicans led the state to join 39 others that have expanded Medicaid.
articles.abstract: Intense patient advocacy, shifting politics, a determined Democratic governor and a handful of maverick Republicans led the state to join 39 others that have expanded Medicaid.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — People who watch politics in North Carolina say that Phil Berger, a Republican who calls himself a fiscal conservative and a “social traditionalist,” is the most powerful man in the state. For years, as the top Republican in the State Senate, he blocked North Carolina from expanding Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Leaked Documents Suggest Ukrainian Air Defense Is in Peril if Not Reinforced
articles.snippet: A huge influx of munitions is needed to keep Russia’s air force from changing the course of the war, according to U.S. officials and newly leaked Pentagon documents.
articles.abstract: A huge influx of munitions is needed to keep Russia’s air force from changing the course of the war, according to U.S. officials and newly leaked Pentagon documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than a year, Ukrainian air defenses, reinforced by Western weaponry, have kept Russian planes at bay.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Michael Schwirtz and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: How the Latest Leaked Documents Are Different From Past Breaches
articles.snippet: The freshness of the documents — some appear to be barely 40 days old — and the hints they hold for operations to come make them particularly damaging, officials say.
articles.abstract: The freshness of the documents — some appear to be barely 40 days old — and the hints they hold for operations to come make them particularly damaging, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on the leak of classified documents.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger

articles.headline: The Real-World Costs of the Digital Race for Bitcoin
articles.snippet: Bitcoin mines cash in on electricity — by devouring it, selling it, even turning it off — and they cause immense pollution. In many cases, the public pays a price.
articles.abstract: Bitcoin mines cash in on electricity — by devouring it, selling it, even turning it off — and they cause immense pollution. In many cases, the public pays a price.
articles.lead_paragraph: Texas was gasping for electricity. Winter Storm Uri had knocked out power plants across the state, leaving tens of thousands of homes in icy darkness. By the end of Feb. 14, 2021, nearly 40 people had died, some from the freezing cold.
articles.byline: By Gabriel J.X. Dance, Tim Wallace and Zach Levitt

articles.headline: A.I. Is Coming for Lawyers, Again
articles.snippet: Previous advances in A.I. inspired predictions that the law was the lucrative profession most likely to suffer job losses. It didn’t happen. Is this time different?
articles.abstract: Previous advances in A.I. inspired predictions that the law was the lucrative profession most likely to suffer job losses. It didn’t happen. Is this time different?
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, lawyers were singled out as an endangered occupational species, their livelihoods at risk from advances in artificial intelligence.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr

articles.headline: China Has Reopened to Tourists. The Hard Part Is Getting There.
articles.snippet: Despite loosened visa rules, the number of flights into China is still a small fraction of what it was before the pandemic, fueled partly by geopolitical tensions.
articles.abstract: Despite loosened visa rules, the number of flights into China is still a small fraction of what it was before the pandemic, fueled partly by geopolitical tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Chinese government announced last month that it would fully reopen its borders to foreign travelers, the news came as a jolt of relief to the millions of Chinese immigrants overseas who have been separated from their relatives since 2020.
articles.byline: By Nicole Hong and Chang Che

articles.headline: DeSantis Pushes Toughest Immigration Crackdown in the Nation
articles.snippet: The Florida governor is pushing an aggressive proposal to penalize those who aid undocumented immigrants and to track costs for providing them with health care.
articles.abstract: The Florida governor is pushing an aggressive proposal to penalize those who aid undocumented immigrants and to track costs for providing them with health care.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE — Led by Gov. Ron DeSantis, a Republican with presidential ambitions, the Florida Legislature is considering a sweeping package of immigration measures that would represent the toughest crackdown on undocumented immigration by any state in more than a decade.
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan

articles.headline: Bank Turmoil Squeezes Borrowers, Raising Fears of a Slowdown
articles.snippet: Economists are watching for the aftereffects of recent bank collapses across many industries. How bad could it get?
articles.abstract: Economists are watching for the aftereffects of recent bank collapses across many industries. How bad could it get?
articles.lead_paragraph: Sarah Puil needs to buy $500,000 to $1 million of premium wine and other inventory by the end of the year to make into the specialty blends that her company sells and ships to customers around the country. But after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank started a chain reaction that is causing many types of funding to dry up, she is not sure where she is going to get the cash.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek
